citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A zebra was observed repetitively making circular motions with its head and neck, scanning a wall of its winter holding
enclosure. Multiple episodes of variable duration, at least one over thirty seconds, were observed during inspection of the
holding facility. A facility representative described this behavior as the zebra "trying to get out." While this behavior did not
occur last winter, it was first observed when zebras were moved from the park to winter enclosures 2 years ago. The
facility shared that it takes a variable amount of time to resolve over the course of the winter and the zebra is otherwise
healthy. The Attending Veterinarian shared that they were alerted to the problem when it first arose, at which point no
intervention was deemed to be needed, but no updates have been given since. Recurring repetitive behaviors, however,
especially in response to environmental changes, may indicate psychological stress and failure to communicate changes
or recurrence may limit the veterinarian's ability to provide updated guidance towards control or treatment. The facility
must provide for timely and accurate information on animal problems with the attending veterinarian.
Correct by December 5, 2024.

A written plan to provide for the humane care and handling of animals in the event of an emergency or disaster was
unavailable for inspection. Inability to produce a written plan to provide guidance for the appropriate care of the animals
during reasonably anticipated emergencies may compromise animal welfare in the event of such emergencies. The plan
must be available for inspection and shall address the response, personnel responsible for the actions to be taken, chain
of command, etc., as required in Section 2.134 of the Animal Welfare Regulations.
Correct by December 16, 2024.

A goat and sheep enclosure at the winter housing barn contains multiple structures in disrepair. The fencing of the
outdoor goat yard includes a fence post with broken outer casings and a section of the barn ceiling over animal areas is
open with broken and fragmented boards. Broken materials and structures may pose an injury risk to animals housed
within. The facility must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to minimize these risks.
Correct by January 6, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not currently have an environmental enhancement plan approved by the attending veterinarian to
promote the overall psychological well-being of birds on the premises. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a
species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of birds that is within
industry standards and approved by the attending veterinarian. This plan must be made available for future inspections.
Correct by December 23, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The enclosure housing waterfowl in the winter holding facility contains an inactive appliance with exposed components,
wiring, and spaces that may injure or trap an animal. There is also an accumulation of dusty building materials and
miscellaneous objects atop the appliance that may pose a hazard to birds. There is a water trough in front of the
appliance that may further encourage animals to approach and potentially engage with the appliance. Primary enclosures
must be kept clean and in good repair to protect birds from injury and facilitate appropriate housekeeping.
Correct by December 9, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A zebra was observed repetitively making circular motions with its head and neck, scanning a wall of its winter holding 
enclosure. Multiple episodes of variable duration, at least one over thirty seconds, were observed during inspection of the 
holding facility. A facility representative described this behavior as the zebra "trying to get out." While this behavior did not 
occur last winter, it was first observed when zebras were moved from the park to winter enclosures 2 years ago. The 
facility shared that it takes a variable amount of time to resolve over the course of the winter and the zebra is otherwise 
healthy. The Attending Veterinarian shared that they were alerted to the problem when it first arose, at which point no 
intervention was deemed to be needed, but no updates have been given since. Recurring repetitive behaviors, however, 
especially in response to environmental changes, may indicate psychological stress and failure to communicate changes 
or recurrence may limit the veterinarian's ability to provide updated guidance towards control or treatment. The facility 
must provide for timely and accurate information on animal problems with the attending veterinarian.  
 
Correct by December 5, 2024. 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
A written plan to provide for the humane care and handling of animals in the event of an emergency or disaster was 
unavailable for inspection. Inability to produce a written plan to provide guidance for the appropriate care of the animals 
during reasonably anticipated emergencies may compromise animal welfare in the event of such emergencies. The plan 
must be available for inspection and shall address the response, personnel responsible for the actions to be taken, chain 
of command, etc., as required in Section 2.134 of the Animal Welfare Regulations. 
 
Correct by December 16, 2024. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
A goat and sheep enclosure at the winter housing barn contains multiple structures in disrepair. The fencing of the 
outdoor goat yard includes a fence post with broken outer casings and a section of the barn ceiling over animal areas is

open with broken and fragmented boards. Broken materials and structures may pose an injury risk to animals housed 
within. The facility must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to minimize these risks.  
 
Correct by January 6, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not currently have an environmental enhancement plan approved by the attending veterinarian to 
promote the overall psychological well-being of birds on the premises. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a 
species-appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of birds that is within 
industry standards and approved by the attending veterinarian. This plan must be made available for future inspections. 
 
Correct by December 23, 2024. 
3.158(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The enclosure housing waterfowl in the winter holding facility contains an inactive appliance with exposed components, 
wiring, and spaces that may injure or trap an animal. There is also an accumulation of dusty building materials and 
miscellaneous objects atop the appliance that may pose a hazard to birds. There is a water trough in front of the 
appliance that may further encourage animals to approach and potentially engage with the appliance. Primary enclosures 
must be kept clean and in good repair to protect birds from injury and facilitate appropriate housekeeping. 
 
Correct by December 9, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
